supporting_evidence.pattern: Emails are dominated by automated security alerts and a vendor newsletter, which do not meet Mitsuhashi’s criteria (voluntary, emotionally meaningful, non-commercial) for authentic ikigai.
examples: New sign-in detected for your Microsoft account (x2) — system/required
Google ad tech remedies trial: Explained — commercial sender (excluded)

supporting_evidence.pattern: No observable learning or consistent personal topics over time.

framework_dimensions.external_connection: Not evidenced. Messages are transactional or commercial; no chosen communities, hobbies, or relationships visible.
framework_dimensions.active_engagement: Low. No signs of replies, event participation, or project-related exchanges.
framework_dimensions.emotional_meaning: Unknown/low. Security alerts and vendor content are unlikely to convey everyday joy.
framework_dimensions.voluntary_pursuit: Low. Security emails are imposed; the vendor email is commercial and excluded from authentic assessment.
framework_dimensions.everyday_joy: No small, concrete daily activities (e.g., cooking, exercise, crafting, club chatter) visible in the email set.
framework_dimensions.growth_orientation: Absent in this dataset; no learning signals or practice streaks detected.

personal_samples.Subject: New sign-in detected for your Microsoft account
personal_samples.Summary: Security alert for Microsoft account sign-in; details provided and instructions to review activity if suspicious.

personal_samples.Subject: New sign-in detected for your Microsoft account
personal_samples.Summary: Security alert about a new sign-in for a Microsoft account; review account activity if not recognized.

personal_samples.Subject: Google ad tech remedies trial: Explained
personal_samples.Summary: Newsletter summarizing updates on Google's ad tech remedies trial and related industry insights from The Current Newsletter.

recommendations: Capture authentic pursuits via email: send yourself short notes or photos about daily joys (e.g., morning walk observations, a recipe you tried, a song you practiced) and label them “ikigai”.
Subscribe to non-commercial, community-run updates aligned to your interests (e.g., local library events, volunteer groups, open-source mailing lists, hobby clubs) and engage by RSVPing or replying.
Join a small practice circle (book club, language exchange, running group); use email for coordination and weekly check-ins to create active, external connection.
Start a micro-project (e.g., balcony garden, sketch-a-day, learning a piece on an instrument) and share periodic progress via email to a friend or community list to add accountability and meaning.

Add one learning thread you genuinely choose (e.g., a university extension newsletter, public-interest blog, community workshop notices) and reflect via a weekly email to yourself on what you explored.
Filter transactional/security alerts into a separate folder so personal, voluntary communications stand out for future ikigai analysis.

If ad-tech is a genuine personal curiosity beyond work, seek neutral/community sources (standards groups, research labs, community forums) and engage with commentary or questions rather than vendor marketing.

methodology.approach: Content-based filtering to identify authentic personal communications

framework_principles.external_over_internal: Connection to external world through personal choice
framework_principles.everyday_joy: Small daily activities that bring meaning (seikatsu ikigai)
